name: 2-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-3-phenylquinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3221
Reason: 1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl and phenyl groups both contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C per group, totaling +40°C. The quinoxaline base itself has a melting point of around -10°C due to the presence of a planar, aromatic ring. The methylene bridge introduces additional rigidity, estimated at +5°C. The piperidine ring formation introduces additional rigidity, estimated at +10°C. The 1-ethyl-4-methylenepiperidine moiety may add roughly +20 due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume. The effects are additive.
